title: MS Drugs Cost So Much: Are They Worth the Cost?

content: When I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS) in 1989, there were no drugs to treat the condition. If you had a relapse, they would give a few weeks of steroids and you could get medicines for symptoms, but the basic illness could not be prevented, reversed, or even slowed down.
When my neurologist told me my diagnosis, I asked him, “So what do I do now?” He shrugged and said, “Tie your shoes so you don’t trip, and call me in 6 months.”

I didn’t mind the absence of a treatment because as a nurse, I knew about the loss of control, the hassles, side effects, and the expense of drug therapies. I tried to live as well as possible and waited for therapies to come along. I didn’t even watch too hard to see what has happening with research. I knew friends and family would tell me if they saw anything about MS in the news.

content: Then in 1996, the first disease-modifying treatment (DMT), a drug called Avonex, came out, followed closely by two others, Betaseron and Copaxone. These three became known as the ABC drugs. Some people in my MS support group started taking them.

But I was suspicious. They cost over $1,000 a month, needed to be given by injection, and they were too new to know what the long-term effects would be. Early studies found ABC users had fewer relapses, but their long term progression of disability was not better than placebo. (Those results have improved some in later studies.)

That seemed like a lot of money and uncertainty to me, and neither my neurologist nor my health care system pushed me to start treatment. I didn’t see that support group members who took ABCs were doing any better than I was, and the price of the drugs kept going up.

I kept thinking, how many poor families could have their lives dramatically improved with the money I’d be spending on a drug that might or might not help me a little bit? Looking at drug company web sites showed me they didn’t even know how the drugs supposedly worked. They didn’t make you better; you could only guess if you’d be worse off without them.

content: I was still playing basketball and working a sit-down job at the time. So I waited, and new drugs kept coming out. In 2004, a new type of drug came out and a woman named Pat in my support group started taking it. She got dramatically better, went from walking with a cane to skiing and riding a bike, telling us all to consider taking it.

Most previous drugs had been interferons. They worked by “interfering” with immune system response, hopefully reducing inflammation. According to MS Society UK, interferons may also encourage growth of oligodendrocytes cells, which may repair damaged nerve cells. This medicine was different: a monoclonal antibody or MAB. MABs are proteins designed to bind specific cells, in this case the B cells that attack nerve sheaths in MS. It sounded worth a try, and Pat was doing so well! So I asked my doctor for a prescription.

It was hugely expensive, about $5,000 per monthly dose as I recall. Insurance paid most of it, and they probably bargained the price down some. My copay was about $400/month, but I applied for assistance from a charitable assistance program, and they paid most of my copay. So my share was about $40 a month, not a problem.

content: Unfortunately, the drug didn’t work for me. I was progressing when I started it; and I kept progressing right through it for the whole 5 months. Maybe I was the wrong patient, since like most MS drugs it works better on relapsing remitting MS. Anyway, I couldn’t see spending $5,000 a month of anybody’s money for a treatment that wasn’t working.
The Prices Keep Going Up

MS drugs are a multibillion-dollar business, and their prices keep rising, in many cases beyond people’s ability to pay. According to the National MS Society (NMSS), “Continually escalating prices have created a significant barrier to treatment, forcing higher costs and increased stress for individuals and families, causing a greater burden for people who already live with a life-altering condition. The annual median price for MS DMTs has increased nearly $34,000 in less than 10 years.”

content: An article in the journal Neurology stated, “First-generation DMTs, originally costing $8,000 to $11,000, now cost about $60,000 per year. Costs for these agents have increased annually at rates 5 to 7 times higher than prescription drug inflation. Newer DMTs commonly entered the market with a cost 25%-60% higher than existing DMTs.”

content: What is going on? Drug companies truthfully say new medications are expensive to develop and bring to market, over $1 billion each for a new interferon or monoclonal antibody. However, that doesn’t stop them. In 2024, NMSS listed 28 different prescription DMTs.

Politics drive up drug prices in America. In 2003, when Medicare started paying for drugs, the U.S. government forbade itself from negotiating prices with drug companies. They committed to paying whatever prices the companies set. Corporate lobbying, supported by patient advocacy groups like NMSS, makes it very hard to control prices. According to an article in Neurology , “DMT costs in the United States currently are 2 to 3 times higher than in other comparable countries.”
What Can We Do?

In our Facebook MS community, many people I surveyed are going without DMTs. So that’s an option. There are dietary and other alternative approaches you can find on WebMD, at websites like Health Hero, or many others.
If you want to take a DMT, there are several ways to make them more affordable.
bullets: Four DMTs are now available as generics, and they are much cheaper, like 10% or less of brand names. Because they have been around longer, generics tend to be safer. No surprises.
Financial assistance. Most drug companies and several nonprofits have programs to help people pay for drugs.

Insurance. Writing on WebMD, patient advocate Lisa Lundy advises researching your insurance to find out what they’ll pay for and what the copay will be. She says payments change frequently, and you might even need to change insurance to get a specific drug covered. Or you might need to appeal a denial of coverage, which often works if your doctor signs off on the appeal. Lundy says you can often get your care covered even if you’ve lost your insurance, but you might need help from a system navigator like her.

content: I personally find the cost of medications outrageous, and MS DMT prices are among the worst offenders. I don’t take them, but it’s definitely your personal decision.
